text: following shows run simulation produce simple summary plot. (Setting second argument plot() gives access dozen plot types.) left panel shows position ship dashed curve, whale indicated three curves, top imagined point mass whale interior, one interface sub-layer blubber, one whale skin. (Actually, skin thin seems thick line actually two lines.) impact occurs ship line contacts whale-skin line, 0.3s, lasts 0.5s. middle shows cross section whale skin, blubber sub-layer. Note thinning bottom two layers, indicative high compressive stress associated impact boat. right panel shows Lethality Index (LI), quantity devised examination published reports whale strikes. analysis, reports “Injury” “Minor Injury” assessed lethality 0, reports “Severe Injury” “Mortality” assigned lethality 1. observed lethalities fitted logistic model function base-10 logarithm maximum compressive stress simulation event using [strike()], using published inferred whale ship characteristics. Simulations peak LI exceeds 0.5, case shown , indicative serious risk life whale.  Exercises. Rerun simulation different parameters, e.g. (1) lower speed peak LI 0.5, (2) vary whale length consider effects strikes immature animals, (3) model strikes near mandible, altering thickness, modulus, strength sublayer. (See documentation parameters learn set relevant parameters ship whale, use strike learn setting vessel speed simulation time interval.)
code: library(whalestrike) #> Loading required package: bslib #>  #> Attaching package: 'bslib' #> The following object is masked from 'package:utils': #>  #>     page #> Loading required package: deSolve #> Loading required package: shiny t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200) state <- list(xs = -2.5, vs = knot2mps(10), xw = 0, vw = 0) # 10 knot ship parms <- parameters() # defaults sol <- strike(t, state, parms) par(mfcol = c(1, 3), mar = c(3.3, 3, 1, 2), mgp = c(2, 0.7, 0), cex = 0.7) plot(sol)

title: Using the whalestrike package
text: example shows extract information sequence simulations, create graphical display part default list. clarity, done loop rather using e.g lapply.  Exercise. Look help plot.strike(), learn examine skin stress y z directions separately, explore effect adjusting impact geometry, constant area.
code: library(whalestrike) t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200) state <- list(xs = -1.5, vs = knot2mps(10), xw = 0, vw = 0) # 10 knots area <- seq(0.2, 2, length.out = 100) stress <- rep(NA, length.out = length(area)) # compressive stress [MPa] for (i in seq_along(area)) {     L <- sqrt(area[i])     parms <- parameters(Ly = L, Lz = L)     sol <- strike(t, state, parms)     stress[i] <- max(sol$WCF$stress) / 1e6 } #> Warning in strike(t, state, parms): increasing from 200 to 4772 time steps, to capture acceleration peak danger <- parms$s[2] / 1e6 plot(area, stress,     type = "l", xlab = "Area [m^2]", ylab = "Stress [MPa]",     ylim = c(0, max(stress)) ) lines(area[stress >= danger], stress[stress >= danger], lwd = 3) abline(h = danger, lty = "dashed") mtext(sprintf("Compression stress [MPa]\n(injurious if > %.2f MPa)", danger),     side = 3, line = 1 )

what: Threat dependence on blubber thickness and ship speed
title: Using the whalestrike package
text: example shows create matrix simulation results, order display dependence result upon two parameters. , display shows maximum compressive strain function ship speed blubber thickness. Note contour lines thickened strain exceeds estimate ratio blubber ultimate tensile strength blubber modulus.  Exercise. Explore effect varying sublayer properties thickness graph.
code: library(whalestrike) t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200) # Hint: the following creates x and y of different lengths, # so that mismatches between row/col and i/j values will # yield errors. l2 <- seq(0.1, 0.25, length.out = 5) # blubber thickness speedK <- seq(4, 15, length.out = 5) # in knots speed <- knot2mps(speedK) # stress = peak stress during each simulation, in MPa stress <- matrix(NA, nrow = length(speed), ncol = length(l2)) l <- parameters()$l for (i in seq_along(l2)) {     for (j in seq_along(speed)) {         state <- list(xs = -1.5, vs = speed[j], xw = 0, vw = 0)         parms <- parameters(l = c(l[1], l2[i], l[3], l[4]))         sol <- strike(t, state, parms)         stress[j, i] <- max(sol$WCF$stress) / 1e6     } } danger <- parms$s[2] / 1e6 contour(speedK, l2, stress,     levels = seq(0, danger, 0.1),     xlab = "Speed [knots]", ylab = "Blubber thickness [m]" ) contour(speedK, l2, stress, level = danger, lty = 2, add = TRUE, drawlabels = FALSE) contour(speedK, l2, stress, level = seq(3, danger, -0.1), lwd = 2, add = TRUE) mtext(sprintf(     "Compression stress [MPa]\n(injurious if > %.2f MPa, dashed contour)",     danger ), side = 3, line = 1)

title: Find maximum Lethality Index during a strike — maximumLethalityIndex
code: library(whalestrike) t <- seq(0, 0.7, length.out = 200) state <- list(xs = -2, vs = knot2mps(10), xw = 0, vw = 0) parms <- parameters() s <- strike(t, state, parms) # Compute the desired value and (for context) show it on a plot maximumLethalityIndex(s) #> [1] 0.6931811 # For context, this is how this can be done "by hand" max(lethalityIndexFromStress(s[["WCF"]][["stress"]])) #> [1] 0.6931811 # Show the maximum on a plot (see also the plot title) plot(s, which = "lethality index") abline(h=maximumLethalityIndex(s), col=2)

title: Plot a strike object — plot.strike
text: x object created strike(). character vector indicates plot. choices entries listed , particular order. "location" time-series plot boat location xw dashed black, whale centerline xs solid gray, blubber-interior interface red, skin blue. maximum acceleration ship whale ("g" units) indicated notes placed near horizontal axes. acceleration indications report just single value ship whale, blubber sublayer squeezed limits, yielding short intense force spike bone compresses, summaries also report spike duration intensity. spike computed based using runmed() acceleration data, k value set correspond 5 ms, k=11, whichever larger. "section" plot skin thickness, blubber thickness sublayer thickness one panel, creating cross-section diagram. "threat" stacked plot showing time-series traces ad-hoc measure possible threat skin, blubber sublayer. threat level computed ratio stress ultimate strength, e.g. blubber, x$WCF$stress/x$parms$s[2]. vertical scale used subpanels make stack. values exceeding 10 clipped 10, case overall label vertical axis note clipping, although easy see, way often occurs soft layers "bottom " onto bone, yields short period high stress, owing high compression modulus bone. curves filled light gray colour stress/strength values 1, black higher values; makes easy tell glance whether threat level high. "whale acceleration" time-series plot whale acceleration. "blubber thickness" time-series plot blubber thickness. "sublayer thickness" time-series plot thickness layer interior blubber. "reactive forces" time-series showing reactive forces associated skin stretching (solid) compression blubber sublayer components (dashed). "compression stress" time-series plot compression stress blubber layer interior. (stresses equal, equilibrium assumption.) "skin stress" time-series skin stress along-skin y z directions. "lethality index" time-series Lethality Index, computed compression stress using lethalityIndexFromStress(). Values Lethality Index exceed 0.5 highlighted, dotted line drawn value. "values" listing param values. "" . "default" three-element plot showing "location", "section", "threat". drawEvents Logical, indicating whether draw lines events, moment closest approach. colwcenter Colour used indicate whale centre. colwinterface Colour used indicate interface whale blubber sublayer. colwskin Colour used indicate whale skin. cols colw, colour used ship bow location, drawn dashed line. colThreat 4-element colour specification used "threat" plots. colour transitions depend layer plotted. skin bone (.e. bottom top subpanels plot), first colour used stress:strength ratio 1/4, second 1/2, third 3/4, fourth 3/4.  blubber sublayer (.e. second third subpanels, counting bottom), colours defined comparing compressive stress values tau25, tau50 tau75 (see parameters() documentation), first colour stress tau25, second stress tau50, third stress tau75, fourth higher stresses. lwd Line width used plots time intervals damage criteria exceeded. D Factor thicken lines times damage criteria exceeded. debug Integer indicating debugging level, 0 quiet operation higher values verbose monitoring progress function. ... Ignored.

what: Create a function for stress in laminated layers — stressFromStrainFunction
title: Create a function for stress in laminated layers — stressFromStrainFunction
text: Denoting unforced layer thickness \(\) layer \(l_i\) strain \(\epsilon_i=\Delta l_i/l_i\), may write stress-strain relationship $$\sigma = a_i*(exp(b_i*\epsilon_i)-1)$$ layer, assumed stress \(\sigma\) equal across layers. Inverting yields $$\epsilon_i= ln(1 + \sigma/a_i)/b_i$$ \(ln\) natural logarithm.  Therefore, change \(\Delta L\) total thickness \(L=\sum l_i\) may written $$0 = \Delta L - \sum((l_i/b_i) ln(1+\sigma/a_i))$$. Note zero-thickness layers removed calculation, avoid spurious forces.

title: Create a function for stress in laminated layers — stressFromStrainFunction

title: Create a function for stress in laminated layers — stressFromStrainFunction
text: expression easily inverted get \(\sigma\) terms \(\Delta L\) may solved easily particular numerical values, using uniroot(). done sequence N values strain \(\epsilon\) range 0 1. approxfun() used create piecewise-linear representation relationship \(\sigma\) \(\Delta L\), becomes return value present function. (purpose using piecewise-linear representation reduce computation time.)

title: Simulate the collision of a ship and a whale — strike
code: library(whalestrike) # Example 1: graphs, as in the shiny app t <- seq(0, 0.7, length.out = 200) state <- list(xs = -2, vs = knot2mps(10), xw = 0, vw = 0) # ship speed 10 knots parms <- parameters() sol <- strike(t, state, parms) par(mfcol = c(1, 3), mar = c(3, 3, 0.5, 2), mgp = c(2, 0.7, 0), cex = 0.7) plot(sol)   # Example 2: time-series plots of blubber stress and stress/strength, # for a 200 tonne ship moving at 10 knots t <- seq(0, 0.7, length.out = 1000) state <- list(xs = -2, vs = knot2mps(10), xw = 0, vw = 0) # ship 10 knots parms <- parameters(ms = 200 * 1000) # 1 metric tonne is 1000 kg sol <- strike(t, state, parms) par(mfrow = c(2, 1), mar = c(3, 3, 0.5, 2), mgp = c(2, 0.7, 0), cex = 0.7) plot(t, sol$WCF$stress / 1e6,     type = "l",     xlab = "Time [s]", ylab = "Blubber stress [MPa]" ) plot(t, sol$WCF$stress / sol$parms$s[2],     type = "l",     xlab = "Time [s]", ylab = "Blubber stress / strength" )   # Example 3: max stress and stress/strength, for a 200 tonne ship # moving at various speeds. This is a slow calculation, so we do # not run it by default. if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ knots <- seq(0, 20, 0.5) maxStress <- NULL maxStressOverStrength <- NULL for (speed in knot2mps(knots)) {     t <- seq(0, 10, length.out = 1000)     state <- list(xs = -2, vs = speed, xw = 0, vw = 0)     parms <- parameters(ms = 200 * 1000) # 1 metric tonne is 1000 kg     sol <- strike(t, state, parms)     maxStress <- c(maxStress, max(sol$WCF$stress))     maxStressOverStrength <- c(maxStressOverStrength, max(sol$WCF$stress / sol$parms$s[2])) } par(mfrow = c(2, 1), mar = c(3, 3, 0.5, 2), mgp = c(2, 0.7, 0), cex = 0.7) nonzero <- maxStress > 0 plot(knots[nonzero], log10(maxStress[nonzero]),     type = "o", pch = 20, xaxs = "i", yaxs = "i",     xlab = "Ship Speed [knots]", ylab = "log10 peak blubber stress" ) abline(h = log10(sol$parms$s[2]), lty = 2) plot(knots[nonzero], log10(maxStressOverStrength[nonzero]),     type = "o", pch = 20, xaxs = "i", yaxs = "i",     xlab = "Ship Speed [knots]", ylab = "log10 peak blubber stress / strength" ) abline(h = 0, lty = 2) } # }

Sw either (1) whale surface area m^2 (2) NULL. latter case, area calculated whale length using whaleAreaFromLength(). l either (1) numerical vector length 4 indicates thicknesses metres skin, blubber, sublayer bone; (2) NULL set four values 0.025, 0.16, 1.12, 0.1; (3) string "from_species", case four values determined calling whaleMeasurements(). default skin thickness 0.025 m represents 0.9-1.0 inch value stated Section 2.2.3 Raymond (2007). blubber default 0.16 m rounded average values inferred whale necropsy, reported Appendix 2 Daoust et al., 2018. sublayer default 1.12 m may reasonable spots whale body. bone default 0.1 m may reasonable spots whale body. sum default values, 1.40 m, whale radius consistent half-circumference 4.4 m, reported Table 2.2 Raymond (2007).  Note, however, values identical found whaleMeasurements. , b Numerical vectors length 4, giving values use stress-strain law stress=*(exp(b*strain)-1), Pa b unitless. construction, *b local modulus low strain (.e. low b*strain values), b efolding scale nonlinear increase stress strain. exponential relationship mapped whale blubber, using curve fit Figure 2.13 Raymond (2007), values used second layer (blubber); see documentation raymond2007 dataset, see fit done. provided, defaults c(17.8e6/0.1, 1.58e5, 1.58e5, 8.54e8/0.1) b defaults c(0.1, 2.54, 2.54, 0.1). skin defaults set give linear shape (since b small) *b product 17.8e6 Pa, adult-seal value given Table 3 Grear et al. (2017). blubber defaults regression stress-strain relationship shown Figure 2.13 Raymond (2007). sublayer defaults set match blubber, lacking information. bone default b small, set linear function, *b set equal 8.54e8 Pa, given Table 2.3 Raymond (2007) Table 4.5 Campbell-Malone (2007). s Numerical vector length 4, giving ultimate strengths (Pa) skin, blubber, sublayer, bone, respectively. provided, value set 1e6 * c(19.600,0.255,0.255,22.900) reasoning follows. skin default 19.6 MPa rounded value Table 3 Grear et al. title: Update parameters — updateParameters
text: Two important differences argument handling updateParameters() parameters() kept mind. First, updateParameters() check arguments feasible values.  can lead bad results using strike(), e.g. expecting four layer thicknesses specified, also thickness positive. Second, updateParameters() perform ancillary actions parameters() performs, regard certain interlinking argument values.  actions set whale length ship mass, easily-observed quantities quantities can estimated using whalestrike functions.  lw (whale length) supplied parameters() without also supplying mw (whale mass), parameters() uses whaleMassFromLength() infer mw lw. procedure used infer Sw given, using whaleAreaFromLength(). Similarly, parameters() uses shipAreaFromMass() compute Ss (ship area) ms (ship mass), Ss argument given.  Importantly, three inferences made updateParameters(), alters values supplied explicitly. easy supply values, however; example,   modifies base state stored PARMS, increasing whale length 1% increasing whale mass area accordingly.  code block excerpted sensitivity test model,   also used perturb ship mass (inferred area).
code: parms <- updateParameters(PARMS, lw=1.01 * PARMS$lw)) parms <- updateParameters(parms, mw=whaleMassFromLength(parms$lw)) parms <- updateParameters(parms, Sw=whaleAreaFromLength(parms$lw)) parms <- updateParameters(PARMS, ms=1.01 * PARMS$ms) parms <- updateParameters(parms, Ss=shipAreaFromMass(parms$ms))

title: Whale mass inferred from length — whaleMassFromLength
code: library(whalestrike) L <- seq(5, 15, length.out = 100) kpt <- 1000 # kg per tonne # Demonstrate (with dashing) the sensitivity involved in the single-digit # parameter in Moore's formula, and (with colour) the difference to the # Fortune et al. (2012) formulae. plot(L, whaleMassFromLength(L, model = "moore2005") / kpt,     type = "l", lwd = 2,     xlab = "Right-whale Length [m]", ylab = "Mass [tonne]" ) lines(L, 242.988 * exp(0.35 * L) / kpt, lty = "dotted", lwd = 2) lines(L, 242.988 * exp(0.45 * L) / kpt, lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) lines(L, whaleMassFromLength(L,     species = "N. Atl. Right Whale",     model = "fortune2012" ) / kpt, col = 2, lwd = 2) lines(L, whaleMassFromLength(L,     species = "N. Pac. Right Whale",     model = "fortune2012" ) / kpt, col = 3, lwd = 2) grid() legend("topleft",     bg = "white", y.intersp = 1.4, lwd = 2, col = 1:3,     legend = c("moore2005", "fortune2012 Atlantic", "fortune2012 Pacific") )   # Emulate Figure 1 of Lockyer (1976), with roughly-chosen plot limits. L <- seq(0, 18, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Pac. Right Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt plot(L, m,     col = 1, xlab = "Length [m]", ylab = "Mass [tonne]", type = "l", lwd = 2,     xaxs = "i", yaxs = "i", xlim = c(3, 30), ylim = c(0, 180) ) L <- seq(0, 28, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Blue Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 2, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 24, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Fin Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 3, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 18, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Sei Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 1, lty = 2, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 17, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Bryde Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 2, lty = 2, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 12, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Minke Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 3, lty = 2, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 17, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Humpback Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 1, lty = 3, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 18, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Sperm Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 2, lty = 3, lwd = 2) L <- seq(0, 15, 0.5) m <- whaleMassFromLength(L, species = "Gray Whale", model = "lockyer1976") / kpt lines(L, m, col = 3, lty = 3, lwd = 2) grid() legend("topleft",     bg = "white", y.intersp = 1.4, col = c(1:3, 1:3, 1:2),     lwd = 2, lty = c(rep(1, 3), rep(2, 3), rep(3, 3)),     legend = c("Right", "Blue", "Fin", "Sei", "Bryde", "Minke", "Humpback", "Sperm", "Gray") )
